titleStmt.title: [The remedy against the troubles of temptations]

editionStmt.edition: This text is an enriched version of the TCP digital transcription A10602 of text S100006 in the English Short Title Catalog (STC 20875.5). Textual changes and metadata enrichments aim at making the text more computationally tractable, easier to read, and suitable for network-based collaborative curation by amateur and professional end users from many walks of life. The text has been tokenized and linguistically annotated with MorphAdorner. The annotation includes standard spellings that support the display of a text in a standardized format that preserves archaic forms ('loveth', 'seekest'). Textual changes aim at restoring the text the author or stationer meant to publish.

respStmt.resp: This text has not been fully proofread

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 74 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 27 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

publicationStmt.pubPlace: Evanston,IL, Notre Dame, IN, St. Louis, MO

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal . The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: [The remedy against the troubles of temptations]
titleStmt.author: Rolle, Richard, of Hampole, 1290?-1349, attributed name. aut

publicationStmt.publisher: in Fletestrete at the sygne of the sonne by Wynkyn de Worde,
publicationStmt.date: Anno domini. M.CCCCC.viii. the fourth daye of February. [1508]]

notesStmt.note: Attributed to Richard Rolle, but except for a few quotations, the work is not by him.--STC.
B1r last line ends: shall repent.
Identified as STC 21262 on UMI microfilm reel 1288.

Imperfect: leaves A1, title page, D2 and D5 missing and replaced by the British Library with facsimiles from the 1519 edition, the title page of which reads: The remedy ayenst the troubles of temptacyons.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.
